paragraphs.text: Atlanta Fire Chief: I was fired because of my Christian faith.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Kelvin Cochran was five-years-old when he realized that he wanted to be a firefighter
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "My family was very, very poor," Cochran told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "We were living in a shotgun house in an alley - three big brothers, two little sisters."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: One Sunday afternoon the Cochran children heard a fire truck stop across from their neighbor's home
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Miss Maddie's house was one fire
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "That's the day that God convicted me in my heart that I wanted to be a firefighter when I grew up," Cochran said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "All I thought about growing up in Shreveport was not being poor and being a firefighter."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: And God granted Kelvin Cochran the desires of his heart
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The little boy in the shotgun shack grew up to become the fire chief of Shreveport
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: He was named the Atlanta fire chief in 2008 - a position he served until 2009
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: was called to serve in the Obama Administration as a fire administrator
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In 2010 he returned to Atlanta
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: where he was unanimously confirmed to once again be the city's fire chief
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: But now Chief Cochran's storied career is up in smoke - all because of a book he wrote for a men's Bible study group at his Baptist church
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: CLICK HERE
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: TO FOLLOW TODD ON FACEBOOK FOR CONSERVATIVE CONVERSATION!
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Atlanta Mayor Kasim Reed announced Tuesday that Cochran had been fired
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The announcement came on the same day Cochran was supposed to return to work following a 30-day suspension
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "The LGBT members of our community have a right to be able to express their views and convictions about sexuality and deserve to be respected for their position without hate or discrimination," Cochran told me in an exclusive interview
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "But Christians also have a right to express our belief regarding our faith and be respected for our position without hate and without discrimination. In the United States, no one should be vilified, hated or discriminated against for expressing their beliefs."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran had been suspended in November because of a passage he wrote about homosexuality in a book titled,"Who Told You That You Were Naked?"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The book's theme is about biblical morality
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "This is about judgment," Mayor Reed said during a Tuesday press conference
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This is not about religious freedom. This is not about free speech. Judgment is the basis of the problem."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Last November the mayor posted a public condemnation of the fire chief on his official Facebook page
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "I profoundly disagree with and am deeply disturbed by the sentiments expressed in the paperback regarding the LGBT community," the mayor wrote
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "I will not tolerate discrimination of any kind within my administration."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The mayor went on to inform the public that Cochran had been suspended without pay and was ordered to complete a sensitivity training class
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "I want to be clear that the material in Chief Cochran's book is not representative of my personal beliefs, and is inconsistent with the Administration's work to make Atlanta a more welcoming city for all of her citizens-- regardless of their sexual orientation, gender, race and religious beliefs," Mayor Reed wrote
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: So what in the world did Cochran write According to the GA Voice, a publication that covers the LGBT community, there were two items that caused concern
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Uncleanness - whatever is opposite of purity; including sodomy, homosexuality, lesbianism, pederasty, bestiality, all other forms of sexual perversion."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Naked men refuse to give in, so they pursue sexual fulfillment through multiple partners, with the opposite sex, the same sex, and sex outside of marriage and many other vile, vulgar and inappropriate ways which defile their body- temple and dishonor God."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran said he referenced homosexuality on less than a half a page in the 160-page book
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "I did not single out homosexuality," he said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: '. I simply spoke to sex being created by God for pro-creation and He intended it to be between a man and a woman in holy matrimony - and that any other sex outside of that is sin."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran told me that someone within the department obtained a copy of the book and took it to openly-gay city council member Alex Wan
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Wan released a statement supporting Cochran's termination
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and said it "sends a strong message to employees about how much we value diversity and how we adhere to a non-discriminatory environment."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The book caused a firestorm within Atlanta's LGBT community
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there were many calls for him to be fired - a decision the mayor finally agreed to
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "I guess they got what they asked for," Cochran said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Georgia Equality Executive Director Jeff Graham told GA Voice Cochran's "anti- gay" views could result in a hostile work environment
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This is not about his religious views but his about his ability to lead a diverse work force," he said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "It's unfortunate that this had to happen. I feel the mayor has done the right thing to ensure all employees are treated fairly."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The allegations against Cochran amount to a he-said, he-said between the fire chief and the mayor
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Reed said that he had no knowledge that Cochran was writing a book
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: However, Cochran said the director of Atlanta's ethics office had not only given him permission to write the book, but to also mention in his biography that he was the city's fire chief
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran said he gave a copy of the book to Mayor Reed in January, 2014 and the mayor told him he planned on reading it during an upcoming trip
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran also admitted that he gave copies of the book to several members of the fire department - individuals with whom he had personal relationships
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The mayor also took issue with Cochran speaking publicly about his suspension
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However, Cochran said he honored the mayor's guidance and did not speak to the media
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He did, however, share his testimony in several churches
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "I did not dishonor him in the process," Cochran told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran wants to make clear that he does not hate anyone
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "The essence of the Christian faith is a love without condition, sir," he told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "I have demonstrated that love in the fire service for 34 years. There' s not any person of any people group that has interacted with me for any measure of time that can say I have hate or disregard or discrimination in my heart for any people group."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran's plight has drawn condemnation from a number of religious groups across Georgia including the influential Georgia Baptist Convention
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "This is appalling," said Robert White, president of the Georgia Baptist Convention
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This has everything to do with his religious beliefs."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: White told me he believes the mayor succumbed to pressure from the city's LGBT community
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "It's a frightening day in the United States when a person cannot express their faith without fears of persecution following," he told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "It's persecution when a godly fire chief loses his job over expressing his Christian faith."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: And the fire chief's firing could spark public protests and demonstrations from the state's Christian community
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "We're past the point of taking a public stand," White told me
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Christians must stand up for their rights."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cochran told me he is considering his legal options
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: - but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: one thing is certain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He has no desire to get his old job back
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "I believe God has greater things for me," the father and grandfather said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "I love the fire services. It's a childhood dream come true."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: And don't go feeling sorry for Chief Cochran
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: "I'm not discouraged and I'm not downtrodden," he said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This is a God thing and He's going to do great things and He will vindicate me publicly."
paragraphs.label: testimony
